content: Title VI of the Higher Education Act authorizes grants to institutions for enhancing foreign language and area studies instruction. This program has a historical role in establishing area studies departments in colleges and universities. The FLAS program, supported by federal government grants, has a long history of promoting foreign language and area studies in colleges and universities. It prioritizes diplomacy, national security, and trade competitiveness, especially in regions not commonly included in American curricula. Recent interest in FLAS has grown due to concerns about terrorism from foreign regions and the need for greater expertise in these areas. Title VI programs, part of the Higher Education Act, are being considered for reauthorization by the 110th Congress. The program received $93.1 million in FY2007 and $95.6 million in FY2008. The Fulbright-Hays Act, along with other programs like NSEP and Gilman International Scholarship, authorizes various international exchange activities administered by the Department of State. These exchanges involve graduate students, scholars, and professionals in different fields, not limited to foreign language and area studies. The Fulbright-Hays programs, relevant to HEA Title VI, support foreign travel activities for American graduate students and professors. The NSEP, under the David L. Boren National Security Education Act, provides aid for international education and foreign language studies for American undergraduate and graduate students. The NSEA provides scholarships, grants, and fellowships for American undergraduate and graduate students to study in "critical" foreign countries and languages. A trust fund of $150 million was established in FY1992 for this purpose. The NSEA provides funding for scholarships, grants, and fellowships for American students to study in critical foreign countries and languages.
